III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
Description contact with children or parents to be a person who has the ability,
experience, education, and training to perform the duties assigned.
Violation Type Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Allegation The foster care worker and supervisor speaks inappropriately to
the birth parent and engaged in harassing behavior toward the birth
parent. The supervisor has threatened to kill the birth parent if the
birth parent reports that the supervisor left her unsupervised with
her child. Additionally, the worker has made harassing remarks to
the birth parent and laughed and called the birth parent mentally ill
while on the phone with others.
Investigation Interviews:
Birth Parent B
On 2/8/2023 after numerous attempts to contact Birth Parent B/the
Complainant, I interviewed her by telephone. Birth Parent B
reported Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4 is the worker on her child,
Child A’s case. Supervisor 3 is FCW 4’s supervisor. Birth Parent B
reported, FCW 4 and Supervisor 3 have not treated her well. They
have not put her interest forward in court and have threatened her.
She said FCW 4 is very hostile in visits; FCW 4 has slammed
2

doors, made threats toward her, and been very aggressive when
speaking to her. FCW 4 said Birth Parent B will her children back
as long as she is the worker. Birth Parent B said during one of her
parenting visits FCW 4 came in the visiting room playing music,
talking loudly on the phone and FCW 4 made a joke about Birth
Parent B’s disability. Birth Parent B could not recall the actual joke.
She said during another time someone came into the visitation
while she was with family, the person pointed at her and made a
point of saying Birth Parent B is mentally ill. I asked Birth Parent B
whether that person was FCW 4. Birth Parent B said that was
another worker, but Birth Parent B did not identify the worker. She
said it is FCW 4 who is always inappropriate with her or is on the
phone with FCW 4’s family members making jokes about her. She
said the worker should not be talking about her having a disability
and should not be slamming doors.
As to a staff threatening to kill her, Birth Parent B reported that was
Supervisor 3. She reported, the threat happened once during one
of her parent/child visits that Supervisor 3 was supervising.
Supervisor 3 had to leave the visiting room but did not have or ask
someone else to come in to sit on the visit. Supervisor 3 left the
room for about five minutes; and before Supervisor 3 left the room,
Supervisor 3 threatened her. Supervisor 3 told her “You better not
tell I left you in this room or I’ll kill you.” Birth Parent B admitted
there was another worker nearby who could see into the visiting
room. She said all that person did was closed the curtain or
partition that separated the two visiting areas.
I asked Birth Parent B whether she thought the reported statement
from Supervisor 3 was a serious threat to kill her. Birth Parent B
stated she didn’t know. She also stated, “I just think she did not
want it known that she left the room”. She said Supervisor 3 also
threatened her by saying “I better stop telling these White people
about things about her (Supervisor 3).” Birth Parent B reported
“the white people and things” meant, the Children Ombudsmen
Office and complaints Birth Parent B has made to them and
Administrator 2. Birth Parent B said Administrator 2 has been
checking on her concerns and plans to meet with her. Birth Parent
B did not know when that meeting was to occur.
Chief Administrator 1 & Administrator 2
On 2/8/2023 I had a TEAMS conference with Chief Administrator 1
and Administrator 2 related to the complaint allegations. I also
spoke with Chief Administrator 1 onsite on 2/10/2022.
3

These administrators reported they are trying to work with Birth
Parent B who sends Administrator 2 emails and texts daily about
issues she has about her case. Both administrators indicated it is
Birth Parent B’s pattern to express many concerns; and she tends
to make outlandish claims.
Administrator 2 reported Birth Parent B has expressed concern
with Supervisor 3 because Supervisor 3 has sat in on some of the
parent/child visitations. Birth Parent B has expressed concern
about Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4 related to visitations
interactions, remarks she alleged FCW 4 has made to her, and an
issue related to Child A’s hair. Administrator 2 said she will be
meeting with Birth Parent B on Friday (2/10/2023) to address Birth
Parent B’s reported concerns about the case, with the stated foster
care staff persons, and ones she has related to Child A’s father,
Parent D.
Chief Administrator 1 nor Administrator 2 reported a concern that
the allegations against Supervisor 3 and Foster Worker 4 have
validity. To their knowledge there were no reporting from others
that either staff had acted inappropriately with parents.
Supervisor 3 and Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4
I interviewed Supervisor 3 and FCW 4 onsite on 2/10/2023.
Supervisor 3 denied the allegations against her. Supervisor 3 said
she has been nothing but kind to Birth Parent B. She has never
made fun of Birth Parent B’s disability; nor would she. She said
Birth Parent B does have mental health issues; and currently Birth
Parent B is not addressing those, despite the agency referring Birth
Parent B for a number of services.
Supervisor 3 reported she may have had her computer while
supervising a parenting time with Birth Parent B; but she has never
been on the phone during those times. Supervisor 3 denies
threatening Birth Parent B or telling Birth Parent B she will kill her.
Not jokingly or otherwise. She reports encouraging “this young
parent”. Supervisor 3 admitted there was at time during her
supervision of a parenting time that she left the room for less than
five minutes. She had to get a diaper for the child. The father had
not brought any; and there was no one else was around to step into
the room. Supervisor 3 said she and Birth Parent B had a good
conversation about why she had to step away and she thought
everything was okay. Supervisor 3 said, in hindsight she realizes
she should have taken the child with her.
4

Supervisor 3 reported Birth Parent B is the one who has made
threats to others. Birth Parent B has two children in care now, and
Birth Parent B has had her rights terminated to other children in the
past. Birth Parent B has threatened Wolverine staff, who
supervises her son, Child C’s case. Birth Parent B has even
threatened the judge on the case. She said, Birth Parent B
constantly complains about different issues and makes allegations.
Because of Birth Parent B’s constant threats and calls/ contacts to
that agency workers, at one point Wolverine was directing all
communication with Birth Parent B to the supervisor. Birth Parent
has also made many complains to South Central’s administrative
staff about her case. Additionally, Birth Parent B tries to
antagonize her son’s father with little acts, but Parent D tries to
avoid her.
Supervisor 3 reported as far as FCW 3’s interactions with Birth
Parent B, she has never observed FCW 4 behaving unprofessional
or in an inappropriate tone or manner with Birth Parent B. She has
never observed FCW 4 to make threatening actions to Birth Parent
B. She said, FCW 4 knows when to engage with Birth Parent B,
and when FCW 4 needs to back off.
FCW 4 affirmed information reported by Supervisor 3 related to
history of the case, Birth Parent B’s tendency to make complaints,
and Birth Parent B’s interactions with Parent D and Wolverine.
FCW 4 denied the allegations against her. She reported during
parent/child visits she is working. She said if her personal phone
was to ring she would step aside to answer it. She has never
spoken to one of her family members about Birth Parent B. Nor has
she made a joke at Birth Parent B’s expense, laughed at Birth
Parent B or slammed door. Nor has she ever observed Supervisor
3 to do those things, or to harass or be disrespectful to Birth Parent
B.
Analysis Based on interviews, there is insufficient evidence to support the
allegations; or that Supervisor 3 and FCW 4 did not have the
ability, experience, education, and training to perform their
assigned duties.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
5

development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Type Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Allegation The agency worker has lied in court reports, has taken photos of
the birth parent’s child's hair pulled out of her head, and has
refused to provide the photos to the court. Additionally, the worker
and supervisor have interfered with the birth parent’s visits as
ordered by the court.
Investigation Interviews:
Birth Parent B
Birth Parent B reported when it come to her case, FCW 4 and
Supervisor 3 do not put her concerns in court reports. They also
say she is not engaging with her child and that she is on the phone,
which is not true. Birth Parent B said she knows there are camera
in the visiting room that will show she’s not. She said she does not
have a problem with FCW 4 and Supervisor 3 telling her they “want
me to do more bonding with my child. Am okay with that. I just
don’t want it said I’m on my phone when I’m not. And put it in a
report like am constantly on the phone when I’ve only done so a
couple of times”. Birth Parent B reported the times has been on
the phone were times she was talking with her family about Child
A. She said if the agency does not want her on the phone, they
should tell her that.
Birth Parent B reported her other concern is that agency is doing
nothing about the fact that Parent D is 30 minutes late bringing her
daughter to parenting times; and Parent D is picking her daughter
up late from the visits. Additionally, that Child’s A hair is being
pulled out by someone. Birth Parent B said she believes Parent
D’s girlfriend does Child A’s. Birth Parent B noticed bald spots on
Child A’s head and has asked the agency to investigate that. She
said at the last parenting visit, FCW 4 asked Parent D what
happened with Child A’s hair; and Parent D reported that Child A is
pulling her hair out. Birth Parent B does not accept that, she thinks
someone is pulling Child A’s hair out. She said there are photos
which were taken of Child A's head where Child A’s hair is missing
but FCW 4 would not show those photos to the court.
Birth Parent B admitted that when Parent D is late for her parenting
time the agency allows her to have the extra parenting
time/minutes. She said this was also addressed by the judge in
court on 1/31/2023. The judge spoke to both Parent D and Parent
B about timeliness and missed visits. Birth Parent B said she’s
6

okay with that. She said, her concern is Parent D’s constant
lateness and who is doing Child A’s hair. I asked her whether the
agency has discussed her doing Child A’s hair during her parenting
time; and she admitted they had.
I suggested Birth Parent B explore this and other concerns she has
about the case with the agency when she meets with Administrator
2.
Chief Administrator 1 & Administrator 2
On 2/8/2023 I had a TEAMS conference with Chief Administrator 1
and Administrator 2 related to the complaint allegations. I also
spoke with Chief Administrator 1 onsite on 2/10/2022.
Administrator 2 advised that Birth Parent B has two children in
care. Both children are placed with their respective fathers; but
Birth Parent B tends to focus only on her daughter, Child A, which
this complaint makes references to. Birth Parent B has insinuated
Child A’s hair was “snatched” out. Administrator reported Birth
Parent B seems to be trying to get the court to remove Child A from
Parent D. The hair issue was addressed in court at a hearing on
1/31/2023. Administrator 2 said Parent D does have a habit of
being late bringing and picking Child A up for/from parenting times.
Parent D may also need to learn how to better care for Child A’s
hair, but FCW 4 has not expressed any concerns with Parent D
taking care of Child A. Administrator 2 said Child A’s hair is
thinning, there has been some breakage, but that appears to
natural, maybe from laying on those sides, not as a result of a
deliberate act to Child A’s hair being snatched out. She
acknowledged that there were photos taken of Child A’s head
where the breakage appears, but Administrator 2 was not sure if
the photos were reviewed/shown at court. She said the worker and
or supervisor could better speak to that. She reported there has
been discussion at court about Birth Parent B doing Child A’s hair
during the two-hour parent/child parenting time, and that will be
encouraged.
Supervisor 3 and Foster Care Worker(FCW) 4
I interviewed Supervisor 3 and FCW 4 onsite on 2/10/2023.
Supervisor 3 reported no awareness of any court reports
containing untrue information. She denied that being the case for
reports she reviewed and signed off on. She said with respect to
the parenting visits she has supervised, Birth Parent B engages
with the child/children; is not on the phone. Supervisor 3 did not
recall a lack of engagement by Birth Parent B with her child, or a
7

report of her being on the phone being indicated in the court
reports. She believed Parent D’s lateness to the parenting visits
was included. She said Parent D was late to the last parenting visit
she supervised. She addressed that with Parent D; and Parent B
was given an extra 30 minutes. She advised that Parent D gets a
ride to the office, and so he may be 5-10 minutes late. She
admitted he has also been at least 30 minute late picking Child A
up from the visit. This has also been addressed with him.
Supervisor 3 acknowledged the court had instituted special
provisions around Birth Parent B’s office parenting time visits. In
the past Birth Parent B, was to call the agency by 8:00or 8:30am to
report she was coming for the 10:30am visit. That was when
Wolverine was involved pertaining to Child C. Now Birth Parent B
must call the agency the day before to report she plans to attend
the visit. No other special provisions are in place; and the agency
encourages Birth Parent B to follow the court’s recommendations.
As for FCW 3 interactions with Birth Parent B during the
parent/child visitations, and general interaction with Birth Parent B,
Supervisor 3 has observed some of those interactions. She has
never observed FCW 4 behaving unprofessionally or inappropriate
in tone or manner with Birth Parent B..
FCW 4 reported she has never submitted court reports with false
statements. She said Birth Parent B does try to engage with her
children, but Birth Parent B focuses more attention on her
daughter, Child A, than her son, Child C. She said Birth Parent B
being on her phone seems to be related to Birth Parent B focusing
on her GPS. Birth Parent B tries to track Parent D. FCW 4 denied
putting that type of information in the court report. She said, Birth
Parent B sent emails all times of the day or night about multiple
things. She said if she was to put all those things in her court
reports the report would be very long.
FCW 4 reported as it relates to allegations of Child A’s hair
possibly being snatched out, she has no proof of that being the
case. She said, on 1/27/2023 while Birth Parent B was doing
Child A’s hair, at parenting time she noticed Child A has some
areas of hair missing. Birth Parent B noticed it also. Child A had
extensions, and the missing hair was around the edges. FCW 4
was not concerned that anyone was snatching out Child A’s hair.
She knows wearing extensions can pull on the hair, bring about
hair breakage in areas. She said she took a picture of Child A’s
head/hair during that parenting visit. Her intention was to give it to
the court. She still plans to do so. She showed the picture to her
supervisor; and he also spoke with Child A’s dad, Parent D about
8

proper hair care. FCW 4 said this matter would not have been in
her last court report because the court report had to be completed
and submitted to the court 10 days before the court date, which
was on 1/31/2023. She said, Birth Parent B brought this issue up
at that court hearing. FCW 4 explained to the court what she had
explained to Birth Parent B about the hair coming out due to the
extensions wearing and possibly a lack of proper Black hair care.
FCW 4 was unable to show the court the photos on her cell phone
because she lost all the photos on her phone and the issue was
not rectified until after the 1/31/2023 court hearing.
FCW 4 denied that she or any other agency staff has interfered
with Birth Parent B’s parenting time or what the court ordered. She
said both Birth Parent B and Parent D have been late for parenting
times. Supervisor 3 addressed Parent D’s lateness with the
parenting visits. FCW 3 said she has tried to make up visits for
Birth Parent B, but many times Birth Parent B will say she has to
work. FCW reported not knowing whether Birth Parent B is being
truthful about that, because Birth Parent B has not been
cooperative by verifying her work schedule.
Document Review:
• Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
➢ Child A (age 2) entered care on 9/10/2020 due Birth
Parent B previously having two children terminated
on and having untreated mental health issues which
put her child at significant risk of harm.
➢ Child A was made a temporary court ward on
7/17/2021. She has been placed in the care of her
father, Parent D since 9/23/2021.
• Viewed a copy of the photo taken of Child A’s head/hair
which showed an image as described by FCW 4.
• Child A’s last two court reports of which I could not discern
whether they had incorrect information.
Analysis Based on interviews and information reviewed there is insufficient
evidence to support the allegations, or to show the agency workers
did not work directly with the child, the family, and other relevant
individuals related to the service plan and implementation
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency’s current licensing status is recommended.
